intro: Ophiorrhiza subumbellata var. ciliata, commonly known as the ciliate sandalwood, is a flowering plant native to Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Rubiaceae and is characterized by its small, clustered flowers and woody stems. The leaves are typically opposite and have a distinctive ciliated margin, which gives the variety its name. It thrives in coastal and sandy soils, often found in tropical and subtropical regions. This plant is of interest in botanical studies due to its unique morphological features and ecological adaptations.
